bibl.title: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Frederick F. Russell, July 30, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302006]

div1.p: Noguchi has reviewed the letters and reports that Russell sent him regarding the use of serum vaccine for yellow fever in West Africa and believes the serum to be beneficial.

div1.head: Letter from Hideyo Noguchi to Frederick F. Russell, July 30, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302006]
div1.p:
Your letter of July 12, with copies of letter of Governor General
N. Olivier, of French West Africa, has been received in due time. In going
over the reports appended by the Governor General, I gather that no real trial
has been possible in Segou owing to the passing off of the epidemic after the
use of the icteroides vaccine. In Grand Bassam, however, I notice, as we al-
ready knew from earlier communications of Dr. Bauvallet himself, that the
greater part of population received two vaccine injections and that the general
effect was more or less marked and some had sterile abcesses. The description
of the general reactions in English translation is somewhat more severe than in
the original French text. Of 5 cases treated with serum 2 were given too late
to be of any therapeutic value, 1 case given in time was fatal, but the cause
of the fever was not affirmed by autopsy, a point rather important in view of
great clinical confusion that may occur in fibrile jaundice cases met with in
West Coast of Africa. At all events, Dr. Bauvallet reported the cause of death
in this case as due to anaphylaxis. The remaining two cases and one additional
mentioned as the 9th. person who was vaccinated once, but subsequently developed
yellow fever (within 5 days from the time of vaccination) the administration of
the serum caused a very decided favorable change in the clinical picture of the
disease and all recovered promptly. In my opinion the serum was beneficial in
these cases as was regarded so by Dr. Bauvallet himself.

Thanking you for keeping me in touch with the situation in West Africa,
